position.marginalia_text: Satis multi, in magno parui: paucissimi, in paruo Magni.

marginalia.translation: Many are small enough in big matters: very few are big enough in small matters.

position.marginalia_text: Singularis ingenij est, in solis consistere singularibus: ca[e]tera obiter.

marginalia.translation: To endure in singular things only is a quality of a unique intellect: other things go in passing.

position.marginalia_text: Nullius voluptas tanta, quanta Philosophi: ait Hierocles. Quid ni etiam Pragmatici maior?

marginalia.translation: Hiercoles said: 'No one has as much desire as a philosopher.' Is the desire of the pragmatist not even greater?

position.marginalia_text:
Make yourself as lustie, as you can possibly for your life: yet how manie thousands shall you finde =
= lusier, then Yourself, & more actiue?
The fine Pragmatician hath the onlie gift of Expedition in word, & deede.
Pa[e]dantius est, no[n] philosophus, qui no[n] est Aristippus, Rabela[e]sius, Proteus.

marginalia.translation: Pedantic is he who is not a philosopher and who is not Aristippus, Rabelais, or Proteus.

position.marginalia_text: Anie studie, a pastime: anie work, or action, a sport: all occurrents, & accidents in [the] world, tricks, & iests. Whatsoeuer in hed, or hand, all with a dexteritie, & facilitie. Ô gallant Course. Ô braue man.

[p. 199: Necessaria etiam ad unguem Althusij ars Juris propter memoriam: Hopperi ciuilis ratio propter illuminatu[m] discursum: Vigelij repertorium, et ius controuersum propter expeditam, certamq[ue] Praxin:] et Jureconsultoru[m] Logica, alia[e]q[ue] Freigij Analyses propter pra[e]sentem Legu[m], Canonu[m]q[ue] Analysin. Semperq[ue] recordandum, ipsum Jurisconsulti A.B.C. esse regulas vtriusq[ue] Juris, cum Decio, et Dyno: qua[e] sunt in omni pragmatico discursu, disputatione, praxi frequentissima[e]:
Cum regulis etiam Brocardicis Chauferi, id est, verbatim regulis magistralibus Speculatoris, in aureo Breuiario.

marginalia.translation: [p. 199: It is also necessary to memorise by heart Althusius' art of law by means of memory: Hopper's civil reason by means of illuminated discourse: Virgil's repertoire and the legal compilation by means of expediency and certain praxis:] and the logic of lawyers and other analyses of Freigius by means of existing analysis of laws and canon [laws]. And it must always be remembered that the actual A.B.C. of the lawyer is the rules of both laws, with Filippo Decio and Magellanus Dinus: which appear most frequently in every pragmatic discourse, disputation and practice. Also with Kaufer's 'Regulae brocardicae juris', that is, with the expert rules of the spectator word for word, in the 'Golden Breviary'.
